title: Jon 'Bones' Jones gets probation following hit-and-run
text:
Jon 'Bones' Jones gets probation following hit-and-run Steven Marrocco, mmajunkie.com 2:24 p.m. EDT September 29, 2015 Former UFC light-heavyweight champion pleaded guilty to one felony charge of leaving the scene of an accident Jon Jones as given 18 months of supervised probation after pleading guilty today to one felony charge of leaving the scene of an accident involving an injury. (Photo: Bernalillo County Metro Detention Center Photo) 18 CONNECT 13 TWEET LINKEDIN 5 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Mixed martial arts champion Jon Jones on Tuesday pleaded guilty to one felony charge of leaving the scene of an accident involving an injury, but avoided jail time when a judge granted him a conditional discharge. 
“Mr. Jones, you got real lucky, and in a number of ways, I think you need to talk to young people because making one stupid decision changes your entire future,” Judge Charles Brown of the Second Judicial District Court in Albuquerque, New Mexico, said Tuesday during the former UFC light-heavyweight champion’s hearing. 
Jones, an Ithaca resident and graduate of Union-Endicott High School, was given up to 18 months supervised probation and will be required to make 72 speaking appearances. Under the terms of his plea agreement, he will avoid a felony conviction as long as he finishes probation and completes the speaking engagements without incident, and his probation could be ended earlier than 18 months if the court so decides. 
“This has been a huge wake-up call for him,” said Jones attorney Vincent Ward. “Ever since he walked away from that car, he’s done everything to make amends.” 
Jones, 28, also avoided fines and other restrictions traditionally imposed on parolees such as traveling out of the state and possessing a firearm. 
“I am here to accept full responsibility for what happened, and I hope you can give me an opportunity to redeem myself,” Jones said during the hearing, which UFC President Dana White attended. 
Jones allegedly ran a red light while driving a rented Buick SUV in a residential area of Albuquerque, striking a car driven by a pregnant woman. According to witnesses, he fled the scene and then returned to his car to grab a large handful of cash before fleeing again. An off-duty cop identified Jones as he fled. 
Police found MMA memorabilia and paperwork linking the car to Jones, as well as a marijuana pipe with marijuana, condoms, and snack food. 
Police sought Jones for questionin g and then issued a warrant for his arrest when they discovered the female driver had suffered a broken arm in the accident. Less than 24 hours later, he turned himself in to police and was released on $2,500 bail. 
Ward said Tuesday that the female driver has recovered from her injuries. 
UFC officials ultimately stripped Jones (21-1 MMA, 15-1 UFC), who’s ranked No. 1 the NOS Energy Drink MMA light-heavyweight and pound-for-pound rankings , of his belt and suspended him indefinitely. Daniel Cormier, who fights Alexander Gustafsson in Saturday’s UFC 192 headliner, ultimately won the vacant belt in May after defeating Anthony Johnson. 
Prosecutors missed the initial 60-day deadline to move forward on Jones’ case, lacking two pieces of evidence. If a plea agreement hadn’t been reached, a grand jury would have decided whether or not to indict Jones and proceed to a trial.
